conclusion: The problem involves a conductor rod MN moving in a magnetic field, with forces acting on it and kinematic equations to determine its constant velocity.
The forces acting on the conductor rod MN are identified as magnetic force, gravitational force, and negligible frictional force.
The magnetic force on the conductor rod is given by F_m = BIL, where I is the current, L is the length of the rod, and B is the magnetic field.
The current in the conductor rod can be found using Ohm's law, I = V/r, where V is the voltage across the resistance r.
The velocity of the conductor rod can be found using the kinematic equation v = d/t, where d is the displacement and t is the time.
The displacement of the conductor rod can be found using the kinematic equation d = v * t, where v is the velocity and t is the time.
The time of descent can be found using the kinematic equation t = d/v, where d is the displacement and v is the velocity.

The voltage across the resistance r can be found using the equation V = IR, where I is the current and R is the resistance.
